Fluid Mechanics and its Application in Chemical Engineering

A lecture will introduce fundamental fluid mechanical theory and numerical method including the Euler equation and Navier Stokes equations. The lattice Boltzmann equation is used to solve the Navier-Stokes equations of fluids. A derivation from lattice Boltzmann equation to the Navier Stokes equation will be delivered. Several applications, such as particle suspensions and bio-cells, in chemical engineering will be presented. The purpose of the course is to quickly bring students to the research front.
Particle Technology, Fundamentals and Particle Size Measurement Methods
Particle Technology, Fundamentals and Particle Size Measurement Methods

articles are playing an important role in nearly all industrial and chemical production processes. To design such processes, the fundamentals of the particle behaviour and their measurement techniques are essential. The latest developments in micro- and nano technology and the needs to separate PM2.5 particles due to health hazard reasons, makes it necessary to have suitable particle size measurement methods for small and very fine particles. Latter will be discussed in this course.
The lecture includes the following topics:
Size definition of particles, which have no isometric shape 
Particle size distribution: density distribution, cumulative size distribution, number- and a mass size distribution
Average particle sizes, e.g: mean or mode diameter, 
Mathematical models for describing the particle size distribution
Particle size measurement methods from the cm size- to the nano size range
Sieve analysis, Image analysis, Scattered light methods, Scanning mobility particle sensors,
Laser difraction methods, Sedimentation analysis, Coulter counting technique, 
Cascade impactors
Measurement of aerosol- and dust concentrations in ambient air and in exhaust gases
Particulate matter PM2.5, PM10 measurement techniques:
Particle packages:
Particle surface and porosity: definition and measurement methods
Wet particle packages: capillary phenomena
Adhesion forces between particles: Van der Waal,- electrostatic- and capillary forces
Tensile strengths of agglomerates, pellets and tablets, models
Particle adhesion forces in liquids, Zeta potential, Particle settling velocity, 
Separation efficiency assessment of particle separators: Total separation efficiency,
Grade separation efficiency
Separation of Aerosol and Fine Dust Particles
Separation of Aerosol and Fine Dust Particles

Definition of particulate matter, TSP, PM1, PM2.5 and PM10 and their relevant national and international (European) limit regulations.
Definition of aerosol emission and immission
Assessment parameters to define the operation behaviour of dust separators, e.g: total separation efficiency and the grade separation efficiency
Explanation of fugitive dust emission (e.g: redispersing of road dust, dust emission from handling, transporting of bulk solids and powder materals), which become today more important as dust sources, compared to the point dust sources (e.g:production plant waste gases).
Classification, operation behaviour, mathematical and physical models of all existing aerosol- and dust separators and their compararative particle separation efficiency.
Besides, gravity-, cyclone-, electrostatic-separators and wet-scrubbers, the main focus in this course is laid on the filtering separator, which is among all other separators the most efficient one, especially for the separation of PM2.5 dust particles:
For the filtering separator the following points will be discussed in detail:
Filtering separators for low and high dust concentrations (depth filters, cleanable filters)
Relevant particle separation mechanisms: diffusion, interception, inertia
Definition of the most penetrating particle size, pressure drop models and quality factor for depth filters
Operation behaviour and technical details of cleanable filters (bag house filters), design equations for multi- bag- house filters, hybrid- and electrically enhanced filters (combination of an electrostatic separator with a bag house filter)
